_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: Texas Railroad Commission / Texas Commission on Environmental Quality

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Southern Union Gas Services, Ltd.
Keystone Gas Plant
Executive Summary RMP

Southern Union Gas Services, Ltd. (SUGS) is a publicly held company that has been in 
the gas processing business for more than 50 years.  SUGS operates natural gas 
processing plants in West Texas and Southeast New Mexico.  The Keystone gas 
plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This 
commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, 
such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, 
operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement 
reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  
However, if a release does occur, trained gas plant personnel will respond to 
control and contain the release.  

This facility gathers field natural gas for processing.  The facility and system 
of pipelines is jurisdictional to the Environmental Protection Agency, Texas 
Natural Resources Conservation Commission, Texas Railroad Commission, the 
Occupational Safety and Health Administration, and the United States Department 
of Transportation.  This facility is covered by OSHA PSM standard.  These agencies
conduct periodic facility inspections and report findings to SUGS management.

The Keystone Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention.  Over the past
5 years there have been no incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have
resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental
loss, or personal injury at this facility.

The Keystone gas plant is located northeast of Kermit, in Winkler County, Texas.  
The plant operates a variety of processes to separate raw natural gas into 
methane gas and natural gas liquid (NGL) product "Product", with black gasoline
and scrubber oil (compression liquids) as by-products.

Several regulated flammables occur as various mixtures in the natural gas stream

being processed and in the produced liquids.  These are methane, ethane, butane, 
propane, and pentane.  These mixtures meet the NFPA 4 flammability criteria, and 
the mixtures are present in amounts above the threshold quantity.  Propylene and 
methyl alcohol, also regulated flammables, are purchased for use in the 
refrigeration of the gas stream for processing, and for de-icing as needed of 
internal components during processing, respectively.

Two regulated toxics are present: the plant purchases chlorine gas for use at 
its cooling towers, and hydrogen sulfide gas occurs in, and is removed from, the 
raw natural gas.  The quantity on hand of each of these toxics is less than the 
threshold quantity, so they are not covered processes under the RMP.  However, 
both of these toxics are addressed in our existing emergency action plan.  In 
addition, the hydrogen sulfide gas is covered under Texas Statewide Rule 36, 
that deals with the protection of the general public. This facility does not 
have a threshold planning quantity of any toxic; therefore, a worst-case 
scenario (WCS) for a toxic release was not evaluated.  

Covered processes involving regulated flammable substances are all Program Level 
1.  There are no public or environmental receptors within any endpoint.  
Although Program Level 1 limits scenarios to overpressure resulting from a VCE 
involving the entire vessel contents, it should be noted that the farthest 
overpressure endpoint of 0.60 mile is unrealistically high, in that this is an 
atmospheric storage vessel with hydrocarbon liquid at ambient temperature.  A 
realistic scenario would be a pool fire for the contents of this vessel, which 
would yield an endpoint of 0.39 mile rather that the 0.60 mile, which results 
from a VCE.


The Keystone gas plant maintains a written emergency action program, which is in 
place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The 
program consists of proced

ures for responding to a release of a regulated 
substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable 
substance is accidentally released, and includes names and telephone numbers of 
contact persons for SUGS, for surrounding public receptors, for 
emergency responders, and for affected agencies.  The Keystone gas plant has 
around-the-clock communications capability and staff.  This provides a means of 
notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick 
response to an incident.  Our facility has 34 full time employees and operates 
24 hours/day and 365 days/year.

The emergency response program for the Keystone gas plant is coordinated with 
the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) for Winkler County.
